questions.text: Which drug causes the given presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Topical PG Analogues

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Topical Steroids are used in the treatment of Cystoid Macular Edema .
  • • Option A
  • • Topical Steroids
  • • Cystoid Macular Edema
  • • Option B . Topical Beta Blockers are commonly used for glaucoma treatment and do not typically cause Cystoid Macular Edema. Their primary mechanism of action is reducing aqueous humor production in the eye .
  • • Option B
  • • Topical Beta Blockers
  • • glaucoma treatment
  • • primary mechanism
  • • action
  • • reducing aqueous humor production
  • • eye
  • • Option D . Topical Cycloplegics are used to paralyze the ciliary muscle and dilate the pupil . While they have various effects on the eye , they are not typically associated with causing Cystoid Macular Edema .
  • • Option D
  • • Topical Cycloplegics
  • • paralyze
  • • ciliary muscle
  • • dilate
  • • pupil
  • • eye
  • • causing Cystoid Macular Edema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Topical Prostaglandin Analogues can cause Cystoid Macular Edema .
  • ➤ Topical Prostaglandin Analogues
  • ➤ Cystoid Macular Edema

questions.text: Ocriplasmin is used in treatment of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vitreomacular Traction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Diabetic Macular Edema (DME) is a complication of Diabetes characterized by Intraretinal Fluid Accumulation due to Microleakage from capillaries . Treatments for DME typically involve Anti-VEGF Injections, Corticosteroids , and Laser Therapy .
  • • Option A
  • • Diabetes
  • • Intraretinal Fluid Accumulation
  • • Microleakage
  • • capillaries
  • • Anti-VEGF Injections, Corticosteroids
  • • Laser Therapy
  • • Option B . Keratoconus is a Degenerative Disorder of the Cornea characterised by thinning and Ectasia which cause the Cornea to become Conical in shape . Treatment options for keratoconus include corneal cross-linking , custom soft contact lenses , and corneal transplant in advanced cases.
  • • Option B
  • • Degenerative Disorder
  • • Cornea
  • • thinning
  • • Ectasia
  • • Cornea
  • • become Conical
  • • shape
  • • keratoconus
  • • corneal cross-linking
  • • custom soft contact lenses
  • • corneal transplant
  • • Option D . The primary treatments for Primary Open Angle Glaucoma (POAG) are medications that reduce intraocular pressure , laser therapy , and surgical procedures .
  • • Option D
  • • Primary Open Angle Glaucoma (POAG)
  • • medications
  • • reduce intraocular pressure
  • • laser therapy
  • • surgical procedures

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ocriplasmin is primarily used in the treatment of Vitreomacular Traction (VMT) . It works by enzymatically dissolving the proteins that cause the vitreous to adhere to the macula , thus relieving the traction that can impair vision .
  • ➤ treatment
  • ➤ Vitreomacular Traction (VMT)
  • ➤ enzymatically dissolving
  • ➤ proteins
  • ➤ cause
  • ➤ vitreous
  • ➤ adhere
  • ➤ macula
  • ➤ relieving
  • ➤ traction
  • ➤ can impair vision
  • ➤ Ref: KANSKI 9 TH EDITION PAGE 597
  • ➤ Ref: KANSKI 9 TH EDITION PAGE 597

questions.text: The secondary vitreous concentrates the primary vitreous towards the center of the eye, creating the Canal of Cloquet, which contains a substance that is less optically dense than the secondary vitreous. Where is this secondary vitreous derived from?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neuroectoderm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . The surface ectoderm: contributes to several structures in the eye , such as the lens and cornea , but it is not the source of the secondary vitreous. The surface ectoderm mainly gives rise to structures at the very front of the eye .
  • • Option A
  • • The surface ectoderm:
  • • several structures
  • • eye
  • • lens
  • • cornea
  • • gives rise
  • • structures
  • • very front
  • • eye
  • • Option C . The mesoderm: contributes to various structures in the eye , including the sclera and the uveal tract ( iris , ciliary body , and choroid ), but it is not the source of the secondary vitreous.
  • • Option C
  • • The mesoderm:
  • • eye
  • • sclera
  • • uveal tract
  • • iris
  • • ciliary body
  • • choroid
  • • Option D . Paraxial mesenchyme contributes to structures in the orbit and extraocular muscles , but it does not give rise to the secondary vitreous in the eye.
  • • Option D
  • • Paraxial mesenchyme
  • • structures
  • • orbit
  • • extraocular muscles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The secondary vitreous of the eye is derived from the neuroectoderm .
  • ➤ secondary vitreous
  • ➤ eye
  • ➤ neuroectoderm
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 12/ COMPREHENSIVE Ophthalmology/ 6 th Edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Pg 12/ COMPREHENSIVE Ophthalmology/ 6 th Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient, who is a known case of type 2 diabetes and recurrent myocardial infarction, presents to the ophthalmology clinic complaining of blurred vision in his left eye. He reports that his vision has gradually deteriorated over the past few months. Fundus examination reveals signs of diabetic retinopathy. OCT imaging confirms the presence of macular edema in the left eye. Based on the clinical scenario and findings, the patient is diagnosed with diabetic macular edema. Which is the intravitreal agent preferred in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Triamcinolone Acetonide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . An anti-VEGF ( Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor ) agent , Pegaptanib was one of the first agents of this class to be used for ocular conditions . However, it is not the most commonly used or preferred agent for DME due to its selective VEGF isoform binding .
  • • Option A
  • • anti-VEGF
  • • Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor
  • • agent
  • • Pegaptanib
  • • first agents
  • • ocular conditions
  • • preferred agent
  • • DME
  • • selective VEGF isoform binding
  • • Option B . Aflibercept is a widely used and highly effective anti-VEGF agent for the treatment of DME . Aflibercept has been shown to be effective in reducing macular edema and improving visual acuity in patients with DME . It binds all forms of VEGF-A , as well as placental growth factor , which are key in the pathogenesis of DME .
  • • Option B
  • • widely used
  • • highly effective anti-VEGF agent
  • • DME
  • • effective
  • • reducing macular edema
  • • improving visual acuity
  • • DME
  • • VEGF-A
  • • placental growth factor
  • • pathogenesis
  • • DME
  • • Option D Bevacizumab is another anti-VEGF agent used off-label for DME . It is effective in reducing macular edema and improving vision but is not FDA-approved for this indication. However, it is often used due to its cost-effectiveness .
  • • Option D
  • • another anti-VEGF agent
  • • off-label
  • • DME
  • • effective
  • • reducing macular edema
  • • improving vision
  • • due
  • • cost-effectiveness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In a patient with diabetic macular edema and a significant cardiac history , intravitreal steroid injection ( Triamcinolone acetonide / Dexamethasone implant ) is a preferred choice due to its effectiveness in treating DME and a favourable safety profile .
  • ➤ diabetic macular edema
  • ➤ significant cardiac history
  • ➤ intravitreal steroid injection
  • ➤ Triamcinolone acetonide
  • ➤ Dexamethasone implant
  • ➤ effectiveness
  • ➤ treating DME
  • ➤ favourable safety profile
  • ➤ Ref: KANSKI 9 TH EDITION PAGE 508
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ KANSKI 9 TH EDITION PAGE 508
  • ➤ 2. Giridhar S, Verma L, Rajendran A, Bhende M, Goyal M, Ramasamy K, Rajalakshmi, Padmaja R, Natarajan S, Palanivelu MS, Raman R, Sivaprasad S. Diabetic macular edema treatment guidelines in India: All India Ophthalmological Society Diabetic Retinopathy Task Force and Vitreoretinal Society of India consensus statement. Indian J Ophthalmol. 2021 Nov;69(11):3076-3086. doi: 10.4103/ijo.IJO_1469_21. PMID: 34708746; PMCID: PMC8725123.
  • ➤ 2. Giridhar S, Verma L, Rajendran A, Bhende M, Goyal M, Ramasamy K, Rajalakshmi, Padmaja R, Natarajan S, Palanivelu MS, Raman R, Sivaprasad S. Diabetic macular edema treatment guidelines in India: All India Ophthalmological Society Diabetic Retinopathy Task Force and Vitreoretinal Society of India consensus statement. Indian J Ophthalmol. 2021 Nov;69(11):3076-3086. doi: 10.4103/ijo.IJO_1469_21. PMID: 34708746; PMCID: PMC8725123.

questions.text: Recommended daily supplementation based on AREDS2 includes all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Beta-Carotene

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Zinc is included in the AREDS2 formula . It plays a role in maintaining the health of the retina and may help slow the progression of AMD .

  • • role

  • • health
  • • retina
  • • slow
  • • progression
  • • AMD
  • • Option B . Vitamin E is also part of the AREDS2 formula . It is an antioxidant that helps protect cells in the body , including those in the eye , from damage .
  • • Option B
  • • AREDS2 formula
  • • antioxidant
  • • protect cells
  • • body
  • • eye
  • • from damage
  • • Option D . Lutein, along with zeaxanthin , replaced beta-carotene in the AREDS2 formula . These carotenoids are believed to be beneficial for eye health , particularly in reducing the risk or slowing the progression of AMD .
  • • Option D
  • • zeaxanthin
  • • replaced beta-carotene
  • • AREDS2 formula
  • • carotenoids
  • • beneficial
  • • eye health
  • • reducing
  • • risk
  • • slowing
  • • progression
  • • AMD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Based on the findings of AREDS2 , the recommended daily supplementation for age-related macular degeneration includes zinc , vitamin E , and lutein , but not beta-carotene, which was removed due to its associated risks , particularly in smokers .

questions.text: Which of the following Anti – VEGF binds with placental growth factor?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aflibercept

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Pegaptanib is an anti-VEGF medication that selectively binds to VEGF-165 isoform . However, it does not bind to placental growth factor.
  • • Option A
  • • Pegaptanib
  • • anti-VEGF medication
  • • selectively binds
  • • VEGF-165
  • • isoform
  • • Option C . Ranibizumab ( Lucentis ) is a monoclonal antibody fragment that binds to and inhibits VEGF-A . It does not bind to placental growth factor.
  • • Option C
  • • Ranibizumab
  • • Lucentis
  • • monoclonal antibody fragment
  • • binds
  • • inhibits VEGF-A
  • • Option D . Bevacizumab ( Avastin ) is a full-length monoclonal antibody that binds to VEGF-A but, like Ranibizumab and Pegaptanib, does not bind to placental growth factor.
  • • Option D
  • • Bevacizumab
  • • Avastin
  • • full-length monoclonal antibody
  • • binds
  • • VEGF-A
  • • Ranibizumab
  • • Pegaptanib,

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Aflibercept is unique among the listed anti-VEGF agents in that it binds both to VEGF-A and placental growth factor . This dual binding ability is relevant in its use for treating conditions like wet age-related macular degeneration and diabetic macular edema , where both VEGF and placental growth factor play a role in pathogenesis .
  • ➤ Aflibercept
  • ➤ unique
  • ➤ listed anti-VEGF agents
  • ➤ binds both
  • ➤ VEGF-A
  • ➤ placental growth factor
  • ➤ dual binding ability
  • ➤ relevant
  • ➤ wet age-related macular degeneration
  • ➤ diabetic macular edema
  • ➤ both VEGF
  • ➤ placental growth factor
  • ➤ pathogenesis
  • ➤ Ref: KANSKI 9 TH EDITION PAGE 587
  • ➤ Ref:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of pulmonary tuberculosis presents to the ophthalmology clinic for a routine eye examination. The patient has been on ATT since 4 months. Which type of colour defect is associated with ethambutol, an ATT drug?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Red-Green Defect

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Red Desaturation is not typically associated with ethambutol. Red desaturation is more commonly associated with optic nerve disorders like optic neuritis .
  • • Option A
  • • not typically associated
  • • optic nerve disorders
  • • optic neuritis
  • • Option B . Blue-Green Defect: Ethambutol toxicity can lead to a blue-yellow color vision defect . Blue-yellow defect is the earliest colour defect to develop in ethambutol toxicity , however red-green defect is the commonest .
  • • Option B
  • • Ethambutol toxicity
  • • lead
  • • blue-yellow color vision defect
  • • Blue-yellow defect
  • • earliest colour defect
  • • develop
  • • ethambutol toxicity
  • • red-green defect
  • • commonest
  • • Option C . Green Desaturation: This type of color defect is not typically associated with ethambutol toxicity.
  • • Option C
  • • not typically

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ethambutol , an antitubercular therapy drug , is commonly associated with a red-green color vision defect .
  • ➤ Ethambutol
  • ➤ antitubercular therapy
  • ➤ drug
  • ➤ red-green color
  • ➤ vision defect
  • ➤ Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF EYE 22 ND EDITION PAGE 244
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ PARSONS DISEASES OF EYE 22 ND EDITION PAGE 244

Indian J Ophthalmol. 2021 Dec;69(12):3734-3739. doi: 10.4103/ijo.IJO_3746_20. PMID: 34827033; PMCID: PMC8837289

questions.text: Maximum allowed dosage of hydroxychloroquine to avoid development of Bull’s eye maculopathy is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 4.5mg/kg/day

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • As per the American Academy of Ophthalmology Recommendations on Screening for Chloroquine and Hydroxychloroquine Retinopathy - 2016 , the limit for maximum daily HCQ use is < 5.0 mg/kg real weight , which correlates better with risk than ideal weight . There are no similar demographic data for CQ, but dose comparisons in older literature suggest using <2.3 mg/kg real weight. Screening for toxicity: A baseline fundus examination should be performed to rule out preexisting maculopathy . Annual screening after 5 years for patients on acceptable doses and without major risk factors . Screening Tests: The primary screening tests are automated visual fields plus spectral-domain optical coherence tomography (SD OCT). These should look beyond the central macula in Asian patients . The multifocal electroretinogram (mfERG) can provide objective corroboration for visual fields , and fundus autofluorescence (FAF) can show damage topographically. Modern screening should detect retinopathy before it is visible in the fundus
  • • As per the American Academy of Ophthalmology Recommendations on Screening for Chloroquine and Hydroxychloroquine Retinopathy - 2016 , the limit for maximum daily HCQ use is < 5.0 mg/kg real weight , which correlates better with risk than ideal weight . There are no similar demographic data for CQ, but dose comparisons in older literature suggest using <2.3 mg/kg real weight.
  • • American Academy of Ophthalmology
  • • Chloroquine
  • • Hydroxychloroquine Retinopathy

  • • < 5.0 mg/kg real weight
  • • correlates
  • • risk
  • • than
  • • ideal weight
  • • Screening for toxicity: A baseline fundus examination should be performed to rule out preexisting maculopathy .
  • • baseline fundus examination
  • • performed
  • • rule out preexisting maculopathy
  • • Annual screening after 5 years for patients on acceptable doses and without major risk factors .
  • • Annual screening
  • • after 5 years
  • • acceptable
  • • doses

  • • Screening Tests: The primary screening tests are automated visual fields plus spectral-domain optical coherence tomography (SD OCT). These should look beyond the central macula in Asian patients .
  • • automated visual fields
  • • spectral-domain optical coherence tomography (SD OCT).
  • • beyond
  • • central macula
  • • Asian patients
  • • The multifocal electroretinogram (mfERG) can provide objective corroboration for visual fields , and fundus autofluorescence (FAF) can show damage topographically.
  • • multifocal electroretinogram (mfERG)
  • • objective corroboration
  • • visual fields
  • • fundus autofluorescence (FAF)
  • • damage topographically.
  • • Modern screening should detect retinopathy before it is visible in the fundus

questions.text: The insertion of which of these muscles is closest to the macula?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inferior Oblique

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . The inferior rectus muscle inserts on the anterior , inferior surface of the eye . It moves the eye downward .
  • • Option B
  • • anterior
  • • inferior surface
  • • eye
  • • eye downward
  • • Option C . Levator Palpebrae Superioris is responsible for elevating the upper eyelid and does not directly influence eye movement or attachment to the eyeball in a way that would bring it close to the macula.
  • • Option C
  • • elevating
  • • upper eyelid
  • • Option D . Inserting on the anterior , superior surface of the eyeball , the superior rectus elevates the eye .
  • • Option D
  • • anterior
  • • superior surface
  • • eyeball
  • • elevates
  • • eye

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ When considering the anatomical relationship between the extraocular muscles and the macula , the inferior oblique muscle inserts posterior to the equator of the eye while the rectii insert anterior to the equator of the eye .

questions.text: Henle’s Layer is the thickened Outer Plexiform Layer in which of the following region?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Foveal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . The parafoveal area is the region surrounding the fovea. While it is a significant part of the macula and has a high density of photoreceptors , Henle's layer is not specifically characterized as being thickened in this region.
  • • Option A
  • • significant part
  • • macula
  • • high density
  • • photoreceptors
  • • Option C . The optic disc, where the optic nerve exits the eye , does not contain photoreceptors, and therefore does not have Henle's layer. This region is known as the blind spot because it lacks photoreceptors.
  • • Option C
  • • optic nerve
  • • exits
  • • eye
  • • blind spot
  • • lacks photoreceptors.
  • • Option D . The peripheral retina is important for peripheral vision and is rich in rods , but it does not feature the thickened Henle's layer that is characteristic of the fovea .
  • • Option D
  • • peripheral retina
  • • peripheral vision
  • • rich
  • • rods
  • • characteristic
  • • fovea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient diagnosed with Best Vitelliform Dystrophy, characterized by the classic "Egg-Yolk" appearance in the fundus examination, is evaluated for Retinal function. Given this Hereditary Retinal Disorder's typical Fundus findings and its pathophysiology, which of the following statements most accurately describes the expected results of electrophysiological testing in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Electrooculography (EOG) will likely show a normal light peak, while Electroretinography (ERG) will demonstrate Abnormal Rod and Cone responses.

options.label: B
options.text: Both EOG and ERG will show significantly diminished responses due to Generalized Retinal Dysfunction.

options.label: C
options.text: EOG will likely show an Abnormal Arden Ratio, while ERG will remain Normal or Minimally Affected.

options.label: D
options.text: ERG will reveal a significant reduction in B-Wave Amplitude, while EOG will show a Normal Dark Trough.

questions.correct_answer: C. EOG will likely show an Abnormal Arden Ratio, while ERG will remain Normal or Minimally Affected.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) EOG will likely show an Abnormal Arden Ratio, while ERG will remain Normal or Minimally Affected.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . This choice is incorrect . In Best vitelliform dystrophy , the primary abnormality is detected in the EOG , not the ERG. The ERG generally remains normal or minimally affected , as the primary pathology is in the retinal pigment epithelium rather than the photoreceptors.
  • • Option A
  • • incorrect
  • • Best vitelliform dystrophy
  • • primary abnormality
  • • detected
  • • EOG
  • • remains normal
  • • minimally affected
  • • primary pathology
  • • retinal pigment epithelium
  • • Option B . This is not typically seen in Best vitelliform dystrophy . While the EOG shows abnormalities , the ERG is usually normal or only slightly affected , as the disorder primarily affects the retinal pigment epithelium .
  • • Option B
  • • not
  • • Best vitelliform dystrophy
  • • EOG shows abnormalities
  • • ERG
  • • usually normal
  • • only slightly affected
  • • disorder primarily affects
  • • retinal pigment epithelium
  • • Option D . This choice is incorrect . In Best vitelliform dystrophy , the significant abnormality is observed in the EOG , not the ERG. The ERG , which measures photoreceptor function , is generally normal or only slightly affected .
  • • Option D
  • • incorrect
  • • Best vitelliform dystrophy
  • • significant abnormality
  • • observed
  • • EOG
  • • ERG
  • • photoreceptor function
  • • generally normal
  • • only slightly affected

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In Best vitelliform dystrophy , electrooculography (EOG) typically shows an abnormal Arden ratio , indicating retinal pigment epithelium dysfunction , while electroretinography (ERG) remains normal or minimally affected .
  • ➤ Best vitelliform dystrophy
  • ➤ electrooculography (EOG)
  • ➤ abnormal Arden ratio
  • ➤ retinal pigment epithelium
  • ➤ dysfunction
  • ➤ electroretinography (ERG)
  • ➤ normal
  • ➤ minimally affected

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with visual disturbances and complains of difficulty seeing objects clearly. During the examination, you suspect dysfunction in the visual pathway and decide to assess the first order neuron of the pathway. Which of the following serve as the first order neurons in the visual pathway?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bipolar Cells

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Ganglion cells are the second order neurons in the visual pathway . They receive signals from the bipolar cells and their axons form the optic nerve , carrying the visual information to the brain .
  • • Option A
  • • Ganglion cells
  • • second order neurons
  • • visual pathway
  • • bipolar cells
  • • axons
  • • optic nerve
  • • carrying
  • • visual information
  • • brain
  • • Option C . Rods & Cones are the photoreceptors located in the retina and are responsible for converting light into electrical signals . These signals are then transmitted to the bipolar cells .
  • • Option C
  • • photoreceptors
  • • retina
  • • responsible
  • • converting light
  • • electrical signals
  • • transmitted
  • • bipolar
  • • cells
  • • Option D. None of the Above.
  • • Option D. None of the Above.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The first order neurons in the visual pathway is the bipolar cells .
  • ➤ first order neurons
  • ➤ visual pathway
  • ➤ bipolar cells
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 172/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eyeball /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 172/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eyeball /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Which of the following is the 3 rd order Neuron in the Visual Pathway?
questions.correct_answer: A. Axons from Lateral Geniculate Body
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . The visual cortex, located in the occipital lobe of the brain , is the destination of the visual pathway , where the third-order neurons terminate and the processing of visual information occurs. However, the visual cortex itself is not a neuron, but rather a brain region composed of many neurons.
  • • Option B
  • • occipital lobe
  • • brain
  • • destination
  • • visual pathway
  • • third-order neurons terminate
  • • processing
  • • visual information
  • • Option C . The ganglion cells in the retina are the second-order neurons in the visual pathway . Their axons form the optic nerve , which carries visual information to the brain. They receive input from the bipolar cells ( first-order neurons ) and transmit signals to the LGB .
  • • Option C
  • • second-order neurons
  • • visual pathway
  • • axons
  • • optic nerve
  • • visual information
  • • brain.
  • • receive input
  • • bipolar cells
  • • first-order neurons
  • • transmit
  • • signals
  • • LGB
  • • Option D . Bipolar cells are the first-order neurons in the visual pathway . They receive input from the photoreceptors ( rods and cones ) and transmit signals to the retinal ganglion cells .
  • • Option D
  • • first-order neurons
  • • visual pathway
  • • receive input
  • • photoreceptors
  • • rods
  • • cones
  • • transmit signals
  • • retinal ganglion cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The third-order neurons in the visual pathway are the axons from the Lateral Geniculate Body that project to the visual cortex .

  • ➤ visual pathway
  • ➤ axons
  • ➤ Lateral Geniculate Body
  • ➤ project

questions.text: Mr. Singh, a 65-year-old with hypertension, undergoes regular eye screening. The ophthalmologist examines his retinal blood vessels and confirms a normal arteriovenous (A: V) ratio. What is the normal A:V ratio of retinal blood vessels?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2: 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal artery: vein ratio in the retina is 2:3 .

questions.text: The point of maximum visual acuity on the Retina is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fovea Centralis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . The blind spot , or optic disc , is the point on the retina where the optic nerve exits the eye . There are no photoreceptors ( rods or cones ) in this area, so it actually corresponds to a lack of visual perception , not maximum acuity.
  • • Option A
  • • blind spot
  • • optic disc
  • • point
  • • retina
  • • optic nerve exits
  • • eye
  • • no photoreceptors
  • • rods
  • • cones
  • • actually corresponds
  • • lack
  • • visual perception
  • • Option C . The macula lutea is an area of the retina that includes the fovea centralis . It is responsible for central vision and contains a high concentration of photoreceptors . However, the specific point of maximum visual acuity is the fovea centralis , not the entire macula lutea.
  • • Option C
  • • area
  • • retina
  • • includes
  • • fovea centralis
  • • responsible
  • • central vision
  • • contains
  • • high concentration
  • • photoreceptors
  • • specific point
  • • maximum visual acuity
  • • fovea centralis
  • • Option D . The temporal retina refers to the portion of the retina situated towards the temporal side of the head . While important for vision, it is not the site of maximum visual acuity. The highest visual acuity is localized in the fovea centralis .
  • • Option D
  • • portion
  • • retina
  • • towards
  • • temporal side
  • • head
  • • highest visual acuity
  • • localized
  • • fovea centralis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The point of maximum visual acuity on the retina is the fovea centralis .

  • ➤ maximum visual acuity

questions.text: Identify the false statement:

options.label: A
options.text: Deprivation of Glucose for 8 to 10 minutes results in Irreversible Damage.

options.label: B
options.text: Ability to Discriminate between Different Colours is a Function of Rods.

options.label: C
options.text: Retina does not need Insulin for Glucose to Enter the Cells.

options.label: D
options.text: Photopic Vision is controlled by Cones.

questions.correct_answer: B. Ability to Discriminate between Different Colours is a Function of Rods.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ability to Discriminate between Different Colours is a Function of Rods.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . This statement is generally true , especially in the context of brain cells . Neurons are highly dependent on a continuous supply of glucose , and deprivation for this length of time can lead to irreversible neuronal damage .
  • • Option A
  • • generally true
  • • context
  • • brain cells
  • • Neurons
  • • highly dependent
  • • continuous supply
  • • glucose
  • • deprivation
  • • length
  • • time
  • • irreversible neuronal damage
  • • Option C. This statement is true . The retina is one of the few tissues in the body that does not require insulin for glucose uptake. Retinal cells can absorb glucose from the bloodstream through insulin-independent mechanisms .
  • • Option C.
  • • true
  • • retina
  • • few tissues
  • • body
  • • Retinal cells
  • • absorb glucose
  • • bloodstream
  • • insulin-independent mechanisms
  • • Option D . This statement is true . Photopic vision refers to vision under well-lit conditions , and it is mediated by cones , which are responsible for high-acuity color vision .
  • • Option D
  • • true
  • • Photopic vision
  • • vision
  • • well-lit conditions
  • • mediated
  • • cones
  • • responsible
  • • high-acuity color vision

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Colour discrimination is a function of cones . Rod cells mediate scotopic vision .
  • ➤ Colour discrimination
  • ➤ function
  • ➤ cones
  • ➤ Rod cells
  • ➤ scotopic vision
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 146/ Anatomy and Physiology of Eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3 rd Edition
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Pg 146/ Anatomy and Physiology of Eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3 rd Edition

questions.text: ERG (Electroretinogram) is used for the diagnosis & prognosis of which of the following Retinal Disorder(s)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All the above

questions.text: The important Retinal Vessels are present in which layer of the Retina?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nerve Fibre Layer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . The retinal pigment epithelium is a layer of cells located adjacent to the choroid . It plays a critical role in supporting the photoreceptors and maintaining the visual cycle , but it does not contain the retinal blood vessels.
  • • Option B
  • • retinal pigment epithelium
  • • adjacent
  • • choroid
  • • critical role
  • • supporting
  • • photoreceptors
  • • maintaining
  • • visual cycle
  • • Option C . The inner plexiform layer is situated between the inner nuclear layer and the ganglion cell layer . It contains synapses between bipolar cells , amacrine cells , and ganglion cells . Although it is vascularized , it does not contain the main retinal blood vessels.
  • • Option C
  • • inner plexiform layer
  • • inner nuclear layer
  • • ganglion cell layer
  • • synapses
  • • bipolar cells
  • • amacrine cells
  • • ganglion cells
  • • vascularized
  • • Option D . Outer Nuclear Layer contains the cell bodies of the photoreceptors ( rods and cones ) but does not contain the retinal blood vessels.
  • • Option D
  • • Outer Nuclear Layer
  • • cell bodies
  • • photoreceptors
  • • rods
  • • cones

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The important retinal vessels are located in the nerve fiber layer of the retina .
  • ➤ important retinal vessels

questions.text: The total number of Short Posterior Ciliary Arteries are?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 20

questions.text: Central Retinal Artery is a Branch of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ophthalmic Artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Middle Meningeal Artery is a branch of the maxillary artery , which is a terminal branch of the external carotid artery . The middle meningeal artery primarily supplies the meninges of the brain and does not give rise to the central retinal artery.
  • • Option A
  • • Middle Meningeal Artery
  • • branch
  • • maxillary artery
  • • terminal branch
  • • external carotid artery
  • • supplies
  • • meninges
  • • brain
  • • Option B . While the internal carotid artery is a major artery supplying the brain and ophthalmic structures , the central retinal artery specifically is not a direct branch of it. Instead, the internal carotid artery gives rise to the ophthalmic artery , from which the central retinal artery branches off.
  • • Option B
  • • internal carotid artery
  • • major artery
  • • brain
  • • ophthalmic structures
  • • central retinal artery
  • • not a direct branch
  • • gives rise
  • • ophthalmic artery
  • • central retinal artery branches
  • • Option D . The posterior cerebral artery is one of the terminal branches of the basilar artery and supplies parts of the brain , including the occipital lobe and the inferior temporal lobe . It is not involved in the blood supply to the retina or the eye.
  • • Option D
  • • one
  • • terminal branches
  • • basilar artery
  • • supplies
  • • brain
  • • occipital lobe
  • • inferior temporal lobe

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

questions.text: Identify the highlighted structure.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ophthalmic Artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . The Central Retinal Artery originates from the ophthalmic artery , which is a branch of the internal carotid artery .
  • • Option A
  • • originates

questions.text: The strongest attachment of the Vitreous Body to the surrounding is at the level of which structure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitreous Base

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . The vitreous body does not have a strong attachment to the macula. The vitreous is in contact with the macula but does not adhere strongly to it.
  • • Option B
  • • vitreous
  • • contact
  • • macula
  • • Option C . The optic disc is another point of contact for the vitreous body , but it is not the strongest point of attachment. The vitreous can exert traction on the optic disc , particularly in pathological states , but this is not a primary site of firm attachment.
  • • Option C
  • • another point
  • • contact
  • • vitreous body
  • • can exert traction
  • • optic disc
  • • pathological states
  • • Option D . The vitreous body is posterior to the lens and supports its position in the eye . However, the primary attachment of the vitreous body is not at the lens.
  • • Option D
  • • posterior
  • • lens
  • • supports its position
  • • eye

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The strongest attachment of the vitreous body is at the vitreous base , a band of collagen fibers at the ora serrata , crucial for maintaining the structural integrity of the eye.
  • ➤ strongest attachment
  • ➤ vitreous body
  • ➤ vitreous base
  • ➤ band
  • ➤ collagen fibers
  • ➤ ora serrata
  • ➤ maintaining

  • ➤ Ref: Pg 157/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eyeball /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Short Posterior Ciliary Artery is a Branch of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ophthalmic Artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . The Long Posterior Ciliary Arteries (there are usually two ) run forward between the sclera and the choroid to supply the ciliary body and the iris . They are distinct and separate from the Short Posterior Ciliary Arteries and do not give rise to them.
  • • Option A
  • • usually two
  • • run forward
  • • sclera
  • • choroid
  • • supply
  • • ciliary body
  • • iris
  • • distinct
  • • separate
  • • Short Posterior Ciliary Arteries
  • • Option B . The Anterior Ciliary Arteries supply the anterior segment of the eye , including the conjunctiva, sclera , and part of the iris . They are not the source of the Short Posterior Ciliary Arteries.
  • • Option B
  • • anterior segment
  • • eye
  • • conjunctiva,
  • • sclera
  • • iris
  • • Option D . Anterior Conjunctival Artery supply the conjunctiva and are not related to the supply of the posterior segment of the eye. They do not give rise to the Short Posterior Ciliary Arteries.
  • • Option D
  • • conjunctiva

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Short Posterior Ciliary Arteries are branches of the Ophthalmic Artery .

  • ➤ Ref:

questions.text: The Type of Collagen that is not found in Vitreous is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Type 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Type 2 Collagen is indeed found in the vitreous . It is the primary collagen type in the vitreous body , providing structural support and playing a crucial role in maintaining the vitreous gel structure .

  • • Option C . Type 9 collagen is also present in the vitreous . It is associated with type 2 collagen and plays a role in the formation of the collagen fibrils that are characteristic of the vitreous body .
  • • Option C
  • • present
  • • vitreous
  • • associated
  • • type 2 collagen
  • • plays
  • • role
  • • formation
  • • collagen fibrils
  • • characteristic
  • • vitreous body
  • • Option D . Type 5 collagen is found in the vitreous . This type of collagen is involved in the formation of the vitreous's fibrillar network, contributing to its structure and function .
  • • Option D
  • • vitreous
  • • collagen
  • • involved
  • • formation
  • • vitreous's fibrillar network,
  • • structure
  • • function

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with a history of neovascular age-related macular degeneration (nAMD) presents to the ophthalmology clinic for a follow-up visit. She has been receiving anti-VEGF therapy for the past year with some improvement in her vision. The ophthalmologist discusses the potential use of a newer anti-VEGF agent, brolucizumb. Which of the following is a potential advantage of brolucizumab compared to other anti-VEGF agents in the management of nAMD?

options.label: D
options.text: Absence of Risk for Geographic Atrophy

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Longer Duration Between Injections.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . This is incorrect . Brolucizumab , has a longer interval between injections compared to other anti-VEGF agents, which is one of its potential advantages , thereby reducing frequency of injection .
  • • Option A
  • • incorrect
  • • Brolucizumab
  • • longer interval
  • • injections
  • • potential advantages
  • • reducing frequency
  • • injection
  • • Option B . Brolucizumab has been associated with a higher incidence of intraocular inflammation , including rare cases of retinal vasculitis , compared to other anti-VEGF agents.
  • • Option B
  • • Brolucizumab
  • • higher incidence
  • • intraocular inflammation
  • • rare cases
  • • retinal vasculitis
  • • Option D . This is incorrect . All anti-VEGF agents , including brolucizumab , do not eliminate the risk of geographic atrophy in patients with AMD .
  • • Option D
  • • incorrect
  • • All anti-VEGF agents
  • • brolucizumab
  • • geographic atrophy
  • • AMD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brolucizumab , a newer anti-VEGF agent for age-related macular degeneration , offers the potential advantage of a longer duration between injections compared to other anti-VEGF agents , which can improve treatment adherence and patient comfort . However, it is associated with a higher risk of intraocular inflammation .
  • ➤ Brolucizumab
  • ➤ newer anti-VEGF agent
  • ➤ age-related macular degeneration
  • ➤ offers
  • ➤ potential advantage
  • ➤ longer duration
  • ➤ injections
  • ➤ anti-VEGF agents
  • ➤ improve treatment
  • ➤ adherence
  • ➤ comfort
  • ➤ higher risk
  • ➤ intraocular inflammation
  • ➤ Ref : Tadayoni R, Sararols L, Weissgerber G, Verma R, Clemens A, Holz FG. Brolucizumab: A Newly Developed Anti-VEGF Molecule for the Treatment of Neovascular Age-Related Macular Degeneration. Ophthalmologica. 2021;244(2):93-101. doi: 10.1159/000513048. Epub 2020 Nov 16. PMID: 33197916.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ Tadayoni R, Sararols L, Weissgerber G, Verma R, Clemens A, Holz FG.
  • ➤ Brolucizumab: A Newly Developed Anti-VEGF Molecule for the Treatment of Neovascular Age-Related Macular Degeneration. Ophthalmologica. 2021;244(2):93-101. doi: 10.1159/000513048. Epub 2020 Nov 16. PMID: 33197916.
